channel.title: Programming in D
channel.description: Programming with the D programming language

item.title: 'deprecated', 'extern', and 'extern()'
item.description: Added 'deprecated' that helps with deprecation process of library features, 'extern' that is for declaring external symbols, and 'extern()' that allows interacting with libraries of other languages (extern(C), extern(C++, std), etc.).

item.title: Code Samples .zip File
item.description: You can download most of the code samples that appear in the book as a .zip file.

item.title: Book Index
item.description: The index section of the book.

item.title: Fibers
item.description: Cooperative multitasking in D with fibers.

item.title: Pragmas
item.description: Pragmas that allow interactions with the compiler, including the most recent pragma(inline).

item.title: Operator Precedence
item.description: The rules that specify the execution order of chained operators and the expressions that they use.

item.title: Foreword by Andrei Alexandrescu
item.description: "Instead of falling for getting things done quickly, 'Programming in D' focuses on getting things done properly, to the lasting benefit of its reader."

item.title: Ebook versions
item.description: In addition to the PDF version, now there are EPUB and AZW3 versions as well.

item.title: '.offsetof' property and 'align' attribute
item.description: The .offsetof property to get the offsets of and the align attribute to specify the alignments of struct members.

item.title: Contract inheritance
item.description: Inheriting 'in' and 'out' blocks of interface and class functions.

item.title: The special keywords
item.description: __MODULE__, __FILE__, __LINE__, __FUNCTION__, and __PRETTY_FUNCTION__

item.title: pragma
item.description: The pragma directive

item.title: Nested Functions, Structs, and Classes
item.description: Defining functions, structs, and classes inside existing scopes.

item.title: Lvalues and Rvalues
item.description: Lvalues, rvalues, their differences, and 'auto ref' parameter type that can accept either kind.

item.title: The 'Index' section
item.description: Automatically generated index section for the PDF version of the book.

item.title: The 'Table of Contents' section
item.description: Automatically generated TOC section for the PDF version of the book.

item.title: The attributes of Throwable
item.description: The attributes of the Throwable interface, collateral exceptions, and an example of accessing collateral exceptions through the .next property.

item.title: Selective, local, renamed, and package imports
item.description: Importing modules selectively, locally, under a different name, and as a package.

item.title: @disable
item.description: The @disable attribute to disable special functions of structs.

item.title: Operator overloading for multi-dimensional indexing and slicing
item.description: The templated versions of opDollar, opIndex, and opSlice, and examples of using them to support multiple indexes inside square brackets.

item.title: static this, static ~this, shared static this, and shared static ~this
item.description: Specifying the initial and final operations of threads and programs.

item.title: User Defined Attributes (UDA)
item.description: Assigning user defined attributes to type and variable declarations, testing the attributes at compile time, and compiling the program according to those attributes.

item.title: Memory Management
item.description: The garbage collector, allocating memory, and placing objects at specific locations in memory.

item.title: Type traits
item.description: Using type traits in conditional compilation.

item.title: Data Sharing Concurrency
item.description: Multi-threaded programming in D by data sharing.

item.title: More Ranges
item.description: Useful range templates of the std.range module. Providing range capabilities depending on the capabilities on dependent ranges.

item.title: Mixins
item.description: Template and string mixins that allow inserting compile-time generated code into the source code.

item.title: More Functions
item.description: More features of D functions: auto, ref, auto ref, and inout return attributes; pure and nothrow behavioral attributes; and @safe, @trusted, and @system memory safety attributes.

item.title: More Templates
item.description: More information about templates: Templates can define any kind of code; template parameters can be of type, value, alias, this, and tuple; template constraints enable template definitions only for template arguments that satisfy that template's requirements.

item.title: Tuples
item.description: Tuples, which combine values of different types and make them available similar to struct objects, and TypeTuple, which represents the concept of 'list of values' as seen in parameter lists, template argument lists, and array literal initialization lists.

item.title: Ranges
item.description: The code examples in the Ranges chapter are made const-correct and they take advantage of UFCS.

item.title: Labels and goto
item.description: Labels that give names to code lines and the goto statement that make program execution go to a label.

item.title: Unions
item.description: Sharing the same memory area for multiple members.

item.title: foreach with Structs and Classes
item.description: Providing foreach support for structs and classes.

item.title: Function Pointers, Delegates, and Lambdas
item.description: Function pointers and delegates allow storing how the program should behave at a later time. Lambdas (anonymous function or function literals) make code more readable and reduce boilerplate code.

item.title: is Expression
item.description: is expression, one of the most powerful compile-time features of the D programming language.

item.title: Conditional Compilation
item.description: Compiling parts of programs in special ways depending on conditions that are checked at compile time.

item.title: Bit Operations
item.description: The D features that enable manipulating data bit-by-bit.

item.title: Pointers
item.description: Pointers are variables that provide access to other variables. They are low-level capabilities of the microprocessor.

item.title: alias this
item.description: 'alias this' enables automatic type conversions of user-defined types.

item.title: alias
item.description: 'alias' assigns aliases to existing names

item.title: Contract Programming for Structs and Classes
item.description: The 'invariant' keyword and the use of the 'in' and 'out' blocks with structs and classes.

item.title: Properties
item.description: Properties allow using member functions like member variables.

item.title: Universal Function Call Syntax (UFCS)
item.description: UFCS enables the member function syntax even for regular functions.

item.title: Encapsulation and Protection Attributes
item.description: Preserving class invariants by limiting access to class members.

item.title: Modules and Libraries
item.description: Organizing D programs and libraries as modules and packages.

item.title: destroy and scoped
item.description: 'destroy()' to call destructors explicitly and 'scoped()' to destroy objects automatically.

item.title: Interfaces
item.description: The 'interface' keyword to define class interfaces.

item.title: Object
item.description: The Object class that is at the top of class hierarchies and its member functions toString(), opEquals(), opCmp(), and toHash().

item.title: Inheritance
item.description: Inheriting the members of existing classes.

item.title: Classes
item.description: The 'class' feature of the D programming language, which supports the object oriented programming (OOP) paradigm.

item.title: Operator Overloading
item.description: Defining the behaviors of operators for structs to allow their uses as convenient as the fundamental types.

item.title: Constructor and Other Special Functions
item.description: The four special functions of structs: constructor, destructor, postblit, and assignment.

item.title: Message Passing Concurrency
item.description: Receiving LinkTerminated and OwnerTerminated exceptions as messages.

item.title: Parallelism
item.description: Explain the parameters of the functions of the std.parallelism module: Work unit size and buffer size.

item.title: Immutability
item.description: The consequences of marking function parameters const or immutable.

item.title: const ref Parameters and const Member Functions
item.description: Marking parameters as 'const ref' and member functions as 'const' in order to be able to use them with immutable variables as well.

item.title: Member Functions
item.description: Defining functions that are closely related to a struct inside the curly brackets of that struct definition.

item.title: Function Overloading
item.description: The function overloading feature that enables defining multiple functions having the same name.

item.title: Variable Number of Parameters
item.description: Default parameter values and variadic functions.

item.title: Structs
item.description: The 'struct' feature for defining higher-level concepts as user-defined types.

item.title: Type Conversions
item.description: Automatic and explicit type conversions of D: integer promotions, arithmetic conversions, the to() and assumeUnique() functions, and the cast operator.

item.title: The null Value and the is Operator
item.description: The null value and the is and !is operators.

item.title: Value Types and Reference Types
item.description: Introducing value types, reference variables, and reference types; and their differences.

item.title: Lifetimes and Fundamental Operations
item.description: Object lifetimes: Initialization and finalization of variables.

item.title: Contract Programming
item.description: Contract programming in D: the 'in' and 'out' blocks of functions.

item.title: Unit Testing
item.description: Unit tests for reducing the risk of bugs and test driven development (TDD).

item.title: Installing dmd and compiling programs
item.description: Added how to install dmd and how to compile programs on the command line.

item.title: Message Passing Concurrency
item.description: Multi-threaded programming in D by message passing, provided by the std.concurrency module.

item.title: assert and enforce
item.description: The assert checks and the enforce() function that help with program correctness.

item.title: scope
item.description: The scope(success), scope(failure), and scope(exit) statements of D, which in many cases obviate the need for try-catch-finally blocks and RAII classes.

item.title: Program Environment
item.description: The environment that starts a D program and the ways the program can interact with its environment: return value, parameters, environment variables.

item.title: Lazy Operators
item.description: The shortcut evaluations of three operators: logical or, logical and, and the ternary operator.

item.title: Function Parameters
item.description: Different kinds of function parameters and how they affect the functions and the arguments.

item.title: Immutability
item.description: The concept of immutability in the D programming language, the const and immutable keywords, and recommendations on how to take advantage of immutability when defining variables and function parameters.

item.title: Functions
item.description: The functions that define the building blocks of program behavior.

item.title: enum
item.description: The enum feature that enables defining named constant values.

item.title: switch and case
item.description: The switch and final switch statements, their case sections, and the use of the goto statement under the case sections.

item.title: The foreach Loop
item.description: The foreach loop, one of the most common statements of D. Its use with arrays, strings, and associative arrays.

item.title: Associative Arrays
item.description: Associative arrays, the hash table implementation of the D programming language.

item.title: Parallelism
item.description: The std.parallelism module to make programs run faster by taking advantage of multiple cores of the system.

item.title: The do-while Loop
item.description: The do-while loop and its comparison to the while loop.

item.title: Formatted Input
item.description: Reading data that match specific formats.

item.title: Formatted Output
item.description: Determining the format of printed values.

item.title: Literals
item.description: The syntax of literals of different D types.

item.title: The Ternary Operator ?:
item.description: The ternary operator and comparing it to the if-else statement.

item.title: The for Loop
item.description: The for loop and its comparison to the while loop.

item.title: PDF version of the book
item.description: The PDF version of the book is now available through a link in chapter headers

item.title: Name Space
item.description: The lifetime and accessibility of names of variables and other program constructs

item.title: auto and typeof
item.description: The 'auto' keyword and its use during type inference, and the typeof keyword to get the type of expressions

item.title: Files
item.description: Reading from and writing to files using the std.stdio.File struct

item.title: Redirecting Standard Input and Output Streams
item.description: How to redirect standard input and output streams of program to files and other programs

item.title: Templates
item.description: The 'Templates' chapter

item.title: Strings
item.description: The 'Strings' chapter

item.title: Slices and Other Array Features
item.description: The 'Slices and Other Array Features' chapter

item.title: Characters
item.description: The 'Characters' chapter

item.title: Arrays
item.description: The 'Arrays' chapter has been proofread.

item.title: Arrays
item.description: The 'Arrays' chapter

item.title: Floating Point Types
item.description: The 'Floating Point Types' chapter

item.title: Index
item.description: The index of the book
